segments.text: Okay, can you hear me?
The following interview is with Walt Coughlin, former member of the Secret Service, by Christie Winderly.
All right, the first thing, what were the various states that you were in Vietnam?
I had the opportunity on three occasions to go to Vietnam.
The first would be in 1965.
The second was the inauguration of President Tu and Vice President Ki, which I guess was 1966 from memory.
Then one time after that in late 1967.
Okay.
What was your job over there?
The reason I was there, I was not in the military at the time.
I was there on all three occasions with Vice President Humphrey, who was sent there on a political mission by his president, President Johnson.
And my mission there was a member of the Secret Service to protect Mr. Humphrey.
Were there any particular ways in which you carried out this protection?
Any things that were different in Vietnam than they were ever?
Well, obviously, it was a lot of different because there was a war going on, and there was an element of risk involved.
But the thing we tried to do was work within the confines of the military operations.
And through that, we would...

which work our security by no one ever knew which helicopter he was in we take off in different directions and just the element of surprise with no schedule and we maintain codes and our radios and so on so we worked within the confines of the military in a very secret manner but it was still a very risky operation okay why did you decide to join the secret service couldn't get another job no that's not true um uh when i got out of college i uh
really probably in retrospect would like to go to law school I guess but I didn't have any money so I had to get a job and I had friends that were

in the fbi and i they were talking to me about some of the restraints that mr hoover at the time put on them and i didn't think i was kind of a free spirit in some of those things and i didn't think i would have lasted probably and then i heard about the secret service which i was not familiar with and the appeal of the white house and the travel and so on just it really appealed to me so i applied and i was fortunate enough to be uh to be uh selected okay um
What were some of the precautions the Secret Service had to take in protecting the President and the Vice President?
MR. You mean domestically or internationally or in Vietnam or just in general?
in Vietnam and in the United States pertaining to Vietnam, such as in the demonstrations?
Well, basically, in the earlier question, I think we pretty much covered what we did in Vietnam.
We worked in the confines of the military, and the element of surprise, and we wore the bulletproof vests and all that type of thing that you would do in a combat zone normally.
We kind of acted more like soldiers, frankly.
But from the standpoint of general protection, the policy of the Secret Service protection of the president is organization, scheduling, logistics.
And within all the confines of a smooth operation, you hopefully have real good security.
You have good intelligence gathering.

good communications between different police organizations, motorcade routes and intersection control and ticket control and access control and ushers and everything right down to where everyone sits and when they're supposed to be in their seat.
All that comes under the umbrella of good security.
So basically what you do as a Secret Service agent is try to organize as best you can down to a scheduled minute, sometimes to the second.
particularly for television purposes.
And under that umbrella of organization comes, hopefully, good security.
What were some of the technological developments at the time?
As a result of Vietnam?
As a result of Vietnam and the protection that you had?
Well, the technological developments even today...
The state of the art of technology in every field is just between computers and radios and chips and microchips and everything else.
Every day it changes and improves.
One thing that did come out of Vietnam that I thought was worthwhile was some of the things that we used within the Secret Service.
There was improvement in bulletproof vests and armament.
There were improvements made in ballistics.
There were improvements made in weapons.
There were improvements made in things like I talked to you about earlier, about night vision glasses, where it's kind of an infrared type of glasses you put on.
You can see as clear at night as you can in the daytime.
So some of the technology that came out of Vietnam from a standpoint of security were excellent improvements.
Okay.
What sort of intelligence were we gaining in Vietnam?
You mean we, the Secret Service, or we, the American people?
We, the American people, and we, the Secret Service.
Maybe you can define the difference.
I'm not sure that, in retrospect, again, that our intelligence in Vietnam was very good.
You know, the Tet Offensive, obviously, someone missed the boat.
You know, we kept hearing numbers that were not accurate.
I don't, for whatever reason, I guess you can argue both sides of that.
I'm not convinced that our intelligence apparatus in Vietnam was effective at all.
I knew a lot of CIA guys that were there, and they were really frustrated by it all.
Because you were dealing with the Asiatic mind, which in and of itself seems to be rather secretive.
Even some of the South Vietnamese forces were sympathetic.
to the north, and you never really knew who your friends were.
So I guess from that standpoint, the intelligence gathering was less than adequate.
And frankly, I think it was very poor.
OK.
I was going to go on to ask if it was used effectively.
Do you think that we gained anything worthwhile that could have been used effectively that was or was not?
Or do you think that that question is really?
Well, if there was something
that was gained that could have been used effectively, I certainly don't remember.
And that's not to say there wasn't, but I can't come up with one off the top of my head.
Okay.
What was your opinion of the war before going over for the first time, before you'd ever been in Vietnam?
Probably that of most Americans, that we wouldn't be there if we weren't right, and I'm a patriot, and I just assumed that was the case.
That was my going in.
Did your opinion change at all?
And if so, how and why?
If not, was it strengthened?
No, I think my opinion eventually changed.
It wasn't right away.
The more I observed the South Vietnamese, the more I wasn't sure that they really cared in a lot of ways.
They said all the right things and did all the right things, but the fact is that they're very passive people.
I'm not sure what their educational levels were, but they didn't appear to be very high to me.

And it just seemed to me there were so many of them sympathetic to the North that, and talking to our troops over there, I'm not sure that they knew exactly sometimes where the loyalties lied of the Arvin people.
So I think that's probably what changed my opinion more than anything else, that in retrospect, we probably, I think we went in there with good intentions.
I think we got bogged down in a land war in Asia, which history has told us never to do.
And then it got so political towards the end that all those mistakes just constituted our downfall.
The Americans are very impatient people.
And the thing is that the Asiatics, you know, time means nothing to them, and they'll out-weight you.
They did that to the French at Dien Pin Pew, and they did it to the Americans too.
You made the statement that in the end it got to be very political.
Are you talking politically?
in the United States?
Yeah, yes.
Well, probably in Vietnam too, but I'm not familiar with the Vietnam politics, basically.
In the United States, it got to be very political because of the demonstrations.
The media, I think, turned sympathetic towards the demonstrators.
They turned anti.
I think President Johnson backed himself into a corner that he couldn't get out of.
And well, it was obvious that he did, because that's why he couldn't run for president in 1968.
You mentioned the morale of the troops, or actually the idea, the perceptions of the troops as to who Arvin, which side Arvin was on.
What was the overall morale of the troops?
Frustration, I think.
I think they felt hamstrung for political reasons.
That's the way they interpreted what was going on.
I think they...
If they have a war to fight, let's go fight it.
There's no such thing as a nice war.
So why try to be nice?
If you're going to fight a war, let's fight it, let's win it, and get the hell out of here.
That was kind of their attitude.
But they won't let us do that.
And we're over here getting killed, and no one knows what's going on.
And we read about what's going on in the United States.
What's it all about?
Were there any geographically based differences that you were aware of?

We've heard that the people who were up close fighting with the National Vietnamese Army, that a lot of times they were fighting on a more conventional sense, whereas the people down in the Mekong Delta were fighting more guerrilla warfare.
Well, yeah, there was some of that, but I think mostly it was a guerrilla warfare.
I think the American forces, with all their equipment, all their training, just were not capable of handling the guerrilla warfare.
And another thing is I've had guys tell me that they would be holding a base camp and be overrun by the Viet Cong, and instead of the Arvin forces taking the wall,

to defend, they would just kind of cowl in the corner, and the American forces would go to the wall, and then all of a sudden they'd all be shot in the back by the Arvin forces, because they just, you know, they would be your friend until it looked like it wasn't going to go their way, and then all of a sudden they were, you were the bad guy.
So the American forces were very frustrated by that.

In a sense of the South Vietnamese people, and Arvin in particular, do you think it was a matter of them actually being on the side of the Viet Cong and the North Vietnamese, or do you think it was more a sense of survival, that they really didn't much care philosophically?
I think the rank and file, which is probably what you're referring to, the peasants, which is basically what the country is, they probably didn't really know much about it or care, frankly.
They just wanted to be left alone and grow their rice and stop all this foolishness.
Okay.
They're probably no better off today than they would have been if we'd have won, or no worse off.
Could you describe any of the changes that the morale of the troops might have gone through as the years went by?
Well, I think it was no different than the opinion of our country.
I think the troops eventually started saying, you know, why are we here?
No one will let us do what we have to do.
If indeed we're going to win this thing, let's go win it.
Don't tell us what line we have to stop at or don't tell us who we can't bomb or when we can't shoot somebody.
If you're in a war, it's in a war.
But the troops got very frustrated by that.
Okay.
What knowledge did you have of Vietnam before going over there in a sense geographically, culturally, and militarily?
None whatsoever.
Okay.
What would you say our goals were in Vietnam?
Well, you know, the published goal was that we wanted to stop the...
There was a domino theory of communist aggression through Asia.
And whether that's right or wrong or not, that was the reason we were in there, was to stop the communist aggression against the South.
And then, you know, the domino theory being next was Thailand and next, you know, Malaysia.
Well, we obviously lost the war, but Thailand is still not overrun.
Cambodia, of course, or Laos, is gone.
But I'm not sure that history won't show us that we might be right.
Maybe we did prevent the domino theory.
I don't know.
Do you think that we followed a plan strategically structured to achieve this goal?

No, I think what probably eventually happened was with all the demonstrations and so on, the anti-Vietnam feelings, I feel that Johnson, who tended to be very egotistical, I guess, for lack of a better word, very proud man,
He's a great patriot, really.
But the thing is, I just feel that he was determined to get this thing through, and I think it just wore him down.
I forget what your question is.
I started rambling there.
Just the strategic structure.
So strategically, I think that Johnson and maybe even the military, because he as commander-in-chief runs the military, ran the military,
I think that they forgot what their mission was and got the politics involved in it, and they were worried about reelection and so on.
Everything just went to hell.
Do you think that the American military was overconfident in its approach to Vietnam before Tet?
Before Tet, I think they were, you know, I still think that they feel they could have won it if they'd been allowed to use all their artillery, so to speak.
Mm-hmm.
But they were really, they were hamstrung, and they had never fought a guerrilla war before.
And it was a very frustrating war.

We have a friend of ours who was a forward observer, and he said he laid for two days as a forward observer observing a rice paddy, because they had to cross that rice paddy, and he never saw a movement.
So he called his platoon to cross the rice paddy, and they were all killed.
Laying underneath the rice paddy, breathing through reeds, were Viet Congs.
And they'd been there the 48 hours he was there, and God knows how long before that.
And they just wiped out his whole platoon.
And he said they were just covered with leeches.
So you talk about patience and frustration.
That's a war that we had never known before.
What, if anything, should we have done differently as far as the war was concerned?
Well, if you wanted to win the war, you should have won it, I think.
And probably the best way to do that would have been...
I don't know if you could have bombed them back to the Stone Ages, as General LeMay said, but I guess that's probably what would have happened.
That certainly would have, if they wiped them off the face of the earth, you would have either, you know, for whatever reason, you know, as I say, war is a nasty thing.
And there's no nice way to win a war.
But I think if we went in there and we intended to win it, we should have won it.
And the only way you're going to do is bomb them back to the Stone Age, like Curtis LeMay suggested.
And he was an Air Force general.
He should know something about it.

um could you give me a general comparison of your perceptions at the various times that you were there how they might have changed my perceptions right your perceptions just your ideas i i think i probably alluded to them in the conversation so far you know each time i went back i kind of got more frustrated by it all too you know you hear the same things you just i saw guys maimed by booby traps and you know legs blown off and eyes blown out from concussion grenades and
And it was just, you know, it was a very frustrating thing.
We were trying to fight a war with all this elaborate equipment, and they're out there with sticks and stones, and it was just a frustrating thing.

And I guess the thing that probably turned me against him more than anything else was I got the impression, and I could well be wrong, but it's my impression, that the South Vietnamese didn't really care.
The rank and file, the peasants, I mean.
I don't know about the government.
What political reaction did you see concerning the My Lime Massacre in March of 1968 under the command of Lieutenant Calley?
It's interesting you ask that because the same person I referred to earlier, who laid there for 48 hours waiting to cross the rice paddy, later on was in Calley's platoon when that happened.
And the reason it happened, and few people know this, in fact I've never seen it in print,
And I know this is true because the person who told me was there, and he doesn't have a tendency to exaggerate or no reason for him to lie about it.

What it was, every day or every week or whatever it was, they would take these trucks and all through My Lai, and Cali was their commander, and they would stop like GIs tend to do and give the kids chocolates and cigarettes and all that type of stuff and just kind of have a little picnic.
Well, then they get down the road,
three or four or five or ten miles, and all the trucks would start blowing up for no apparent reason.
And people were getting killed.
I mean, all of them, you know, they were getting wiped out.
Well, what they found out was that when they were stopping, these little kids in My Lai, and the sympathetic people, their parents or whatever, they were taking all the chocolate candies.
When they weren't looking, what they were doing was pulling pins from hand grenades and wrapping a rubber band around the hand grenade and dropping it in the gas tank of the truck.
the same people you're being nice to.
And then when you get down the road, of course, the gasoline would erode that rubber band, and up you go.
Well, the reaction of the people that have been getting their people killed was to go back and take care of the source that was causing this to happen, which were the My Lai kids and families.
And that's where the My Lai massacre came from, and that's why it happened.
And frankly, as a person, if you're really going to analyze war, I feel sorry for Cali.
He did exactly what he had to do.
Okay.
My next question then was going to be your opinion of Lieutenant Calley as a commander.
I take it that you think that...
I don't know how many people he lost, but there were trucks.
They couldn't figure out for several weeks what was going on.
So he lost several truckloads of troops by these same people.
And as I say, war is ugly.
So he went back and he bit off the hand that was doing it.
All right.
What is your opinion of the manner in which the trial of Lieutenant Calley was handled, especially the publicity?
Well, I think what I just said you've never seen in print, and I'm convinced in my heart that it's true because the person who told me was there.
But you'll never see in print that they had any excuse to do what they did.
It's kind of like now you're reading about, oh, terrible President Reagan killing that little kid in Libya.
Well, what about the kid that was sucked through the TWA plane?
No one ever talks about that when they...
when the Libyans bombed it.
So, as I say, there's no nice answer to it.
That's just the price you pay for war and for terrorism.
Besides, what the hell... An adult's life is just as valuable as a kid's.
It's just a sentiment that people seem to have.
Do you think... What sort of reason do you think there is that the media would not be showing things from that point of view?
I can't speak for the media.
They still don't, in my opinion.
They show things that are, first of all, going to create interest, and secondly, sell newspapers.
And the My Lai thing, no one can, I guess, morally go around saying, well, Lieutenant Kelly was wrong for killing kids.
But the thing is, some of the Viet Cong forces were 11 and 12 years old, too.
Are they kids just because they're soldiers?
What the hell's the difference?
If they're killing your people and it's a war, then you have to annihilate them.
Age is not a factor, I don't think.
Do you think Lieutenant Calley was used as a scapegoat for the American people and for the military?
Yes, but I can't give any reasons why.
I mean, it's my opinion that he was.
I think it's a shame that of all the tragedies and all the

all the horrible things that happen in vietnam being single out one person to uh to be tried and convicted i mean i guess you you could do the same thing to every pilot that dropped napalm and burned some little girl or some little kid that never happened that was accepted as being part of war tragic though it is i yeah i think kelly was escaping i sure do um
You've somewhat answered this question, but I'm going to go ahead and answer it again, or ask it again.
What role did it appear to you that the media played?
What's your opinion of that role?
And what effects, if any, do you think that the media had on the war?
Oh, they had all the effect on the war.
That's the first time ever that the American public saw killing on live TV.
We saw the war in our living room.
That's why it was so controversial.
The media, and I'm not saying it's right or wrong, that's just the way that television is today, but that's the first time the American people ever had war in their living room.

They saw it, they had strong opinions for it, or against it for the most part, because as I say, first of all, they're not trained for war, soldiers are trained for war, and they're not used to seeing this carnage.
And they did turn against it, and the media had a tremendous amount to do with it.
Could you give me your perceptions of the domestic demonstrations?
In particular, what was your role during the domestic demonstrations?
How did they change over the years?
What effect did they have on the government?
How did they affect the President in his personal life also?
And what effect did they have on political policies?
THE PRESIDENT.
Well, you might have to  I might have to ask you again some of those things.
But basically, first of all, they started out as a very small group, and then they just grew and grew and grew.
And some of this was from the media.
And they were strong.
For the most part, they were young kids who chose not to go to Vietnam for whatever reason or were opposed to it politically and philosophically.
But the thing was that they got larger as the war went on and they got more militant to where they became very destructive.
I mean, I saw times when I was in the middle of these people with Humphrey
One time at Stanford, they got so bad that, frankly, they were worse than anything I ever saw in Vietnam.
These same peaceniks, so to speak.
And the fact is that they were not that way at all.
They were very, very militant people.
But I have to give them the benefit of the doubt and say they were speaking their conscience.
I don't know that they were.
I think some of them are out there just for a lark.
I think there's some communist infiltration in it, frankly.
I think there's some anti-American infiltration in it.
The media gave a complete coverage.
And the more coverage they got, it's no different than terrorism.
You know, I think it would probably, the reason terrorists do what they do is to get coverage and get sympathy of the world.
And that's what the Vietnam demonstrators do.
As far as my role, and I was in it every day with Humphrey, and it was very difficult, frankly.
We were spit on and kicked and everything else every day.
So it was very difficult.
Now, I specify that it was Humphrey because Johnson, they got so bad, he was a prisoner of the White House.
He could not go out.
And that's why he couldn't run for president in 1968.
It wasn't that he didn't want to.
He couldn't.
He could not fiscally campaign.
They would have kept him off the streets.
And that's why he chose not to run again.
So, yeah, did they set political policy?
You bet your life they did.
They made Richard Nixon president.
A lot of times it's been stated by a number of people that the first...
I guess militant act was by the United States at Kent State in particular.
What do you think about that?
Do you think it was a reaction of the United States government against the demonstrators?
Do you think it was just people got caught up in what was going on and maybe made some decisions that might not have been the best?
I think when it all started out, there were very sincere kids at Kent State, and I say kids for like students,
It's not all more students.
Some of them were runaways and some were renegades.
But for the most part, they were a group of students who were anti-Vietnam and were showing their constitutional right to protest.
And like all these things, they tend to get out of hand.
This one did.
The National Guard was called out for whatever reason.
They were called out.
And then, if you know anything about National Guard, for the most part, they're young guys, too, who've never had any formal training.
They go one weekend a month.
And when it got violent, my guess is, and this is only a guess, that someone somewhere gave the order to fire and a bunch of nervous kids called National Guard soldiers fired.
And they killed some people.
I think it was a misunderstanding on both sides.
I think it was a tragedy on both sides.
It was something that started out very well-meaning and got out of hand, and people died.
What was Two's government like?
You said that you were there for the inauguration.
Maybe you can just give me your perceptions of the inauguration and then any knowledge.
I really don't know what his government was like.
I really don't.
I know Key was his vice president.
He was kind of a flamboyant guy.
Two, the observations I made, was a very, very sincere, interested, anti-communist man.
Now, how he got to where he is, I don't know the history of Two.

uh... whether the election was fair i don't know i do know that he tried to run a democratic type of government and as you know he now lives in connecticut or somewhere he didn't do very well with it and two lives in california or key rather so for whatever i i i really don't know what kind of government he ran it was quasi military obviously but uh... whether he was elected legally i you know
It could be another Marcos deal for all I know.
I really don't know.
Okay.
What was your opinion of the South Vietnamese people?
I found them to be very, for the most part, peasant, for the most part, passive, for the most part, probably uninformed.
They just wanted to grow rice and have babies and be left alone.
But, and again, that's only, that's my perception of them.
The military, I think it was all by conscription.
And they got in the military and they were trained and they were told to go fight your brothers in the north.
And some did and some didn't.
But for the most part, I found them a very patient Asiatic people.
What was your opinion of Arvin?
I don't have very high regard for them, frankly.
And again, I alluded earlier to times when they've turned on our forces.
They would run in times of crises.
I've had both the South Korean forces and the American forces tell me they're not worth a darn.
The best forces I saw there, frankly, were the South Koreans.
A number of people have said that.
The ROK, they call them the ROK forces, Republic of Korea.
And again, they were trained by us from Korea.
They weren't very good in Korea in 1950 either, but they're certainly good now.
What was your opinion of the South Vietnamese Secret Service?
Did you cooperate with them?
Did they cooperate with you?
I never knew they had a Secret Service per se.
I'm sure it was part of their infrastructure of their military.
But any time we were there, we always dealt strictly with the military.
And now if the guy wearing the uniform was Secret Service, I didn't know that.
I didn't ask.
I didn't care.
So again, I have no opinion.
I don't even know if they have a thing called the Secret Service.
You say they did, they did.
Okay.
How much did... Well, I guess this would be a difficult question for you to answer.
I was going to say, how much did you spy on each other?
But if you really weren't aware of the South Vietnam Secret Service, then...
I mean, we had no reason to spy on anyone.
We were there for anywhere from five days to eight days, and we tried to stay alive and get the heck out of there.
I think I'm talking more in terms of maybe just militarily.
Well, you know, we were, again, working within the confines of the American military.
The things we were very careful with was our radio transmission because we knew they were probably being monitored.
But that's true in every foreign country.
You know, we never say anything over the telephone.
We didn't want the world to know.
But that's true of any foreign country.
There's really nothing different there that we did that you wouldn't do if you were visiting today to France.
Okay.
The only difference is people should mention it.
Nice difference.
Were you aware of any corruption within the government, Arvin, or the Secret Service?
If so...
I'm sure that there was so much money going into and aid going into South Vietnam
I'm sure there was corruption involved.
I'm sure there was money that never got to where it was supposed to go.
I didn't see a lot of it.
I used to see Key with a lot of $5 bills in his pocket at times.
But I don't think it's any different than any other dictatorial type of government.
And what the heck it was that, you know, Marcus, look at all the aid we gave Marcus.
Now look what he's done with it, apparently.
I'm sure some of that went on in Vietnam.
Not all that went for milk and honey was spent on milk and honey, I'm sure.
They went in somebody's pocket.
I didn't really see it, but I heard it from people who should know that it was a substantial amount of it.
But my lord, I don't know how many million dollars a day of aid the United States were sending to Vietnam.
You probably know.
But, you know, it was just mind-boggling, the money going in there.
What was it, a million dollars a day we spent in Vietnam?
Something like that.

And if you get a few people that have sticky fingers, you've got a million dollars a day coming in every day, and they only want to steal $10,000 a day, that's not very much out of a million, but if you steal $10,000 every day, that's a hell of a lot.
Yeah, I think there's a lot of corruption, frankly.
Could you give me your perceptions on the following people?
First of all, Humphrey.
Humphrey was probably one of the brightest, most well-read patriots I've ever met in my life.
He was a true American.
Politically, I wasn't in full agreement with him.
I professed to be a conservative.
He professed to be a liberal.
I'm not sure I know what those two things mean.
So we had different philosophies of politics.
But I will say this about him.
He's the only true liberal I ever met.
Most liberals, they scream for busing and put their kids in private schools.
Humphrey didn't do that.
He used to say that he firmly believed that all men are created equal in the eyes of God.
He used to say that he never could understand why it took 50,000 laws to govern 10 commandments.
Well, and that's a very commendable statement.
Maybe naive, but it's commendable.
But that's really the way he was.
He was a very gentle man, a very bright man, and I feel would have made a good president.
I think what he did, because of the television today,

um he came across to the american public as being weak as a weak person the fact is he was a very kind and gentle person and i think they mistook that kind and gentle characteristic as being a weak person i think if humphrey would have been running for president prior to the television era he may well have won it he was not for some reason now you have to be attractive to be president
or whatever the word is they use, charisma, whatever the hell that means.
A lot of people have stated that.
It doesn't make any sense.
Charisma does nothing for you.
In fact, I've heard it say that Humphrey had a very high forehead.
And I heard a guy tell him one time, Hubert, on television, you look like a hydrocephalic.
Well, it wasn't a very nice thing to say, but he probably did.
I think, and getting back to your media question, yeah, I think the media does a lot to influence politics today and not all of it's good.
Okay, what were your perceptions of Johnson?
Johnson was a very strong man, a very proud man, a very well-versed political expert.
He understood all the workings of politics.
He understood the American system to a T. He started from the bottom and went to the top through the political system of this country.
He knew all the soft spots in people.
He understood human needs.
He understood what made people do and don't do things.
He was a master at it.
I think the thing that brought Lyndon down, I call him Lyndon, President Johnson down, was his...
his Texas tenacity, so to speak.
And by golly, I'm always right.
And he didn't listen to his advisors on Vietnam.
And he just got so paranoid about it that it destroyed him.
What about Westmoreland?
I like Westmoreland.
I thought he was a good commander.
In fact, I have a picture out there with him if you'd like to see it before you leave.
He was a good soldier, a very respected soldier.
The troops liked him.
He was always in the field with them.
He was always in the front lines.
Every time we went through hospitals in Vietnam, he was always there.
The troops loved him.
I think Westmoreland's problem was that when you get to be that high, when you get up with stars on your shoulders, then you become part of the political system.
Because I think there are politics involved in everything, not least of which is the military.
So he did have some political pressures put on him.
I think as a soldier, he probably did some things or was forced to do some things that he didn't read in the book of Westmoreland.
But I liked Westmoreland.
I think he got caught up in the politics of it all, too, under the power of Lyndon Johnson, who was his boss.
What about the LBJ administration in general?
Oh, I think probably they're getting a lot of credit for things they shouldn't.
What he did, the LBJ administration did nothing more than continue with the things that Kennedy started.
Johnson got credit for a lot of things that I don't know, but it'd be my opinion that if he were elected president, he would not have done.
I don't think he was a big firm advocate of civil rights, personally.
although he was almost forced to be because Kennedy had already got those things, the Peace Corps and so on, in motion during his three years in office.
So Johnson just carried those things on, which was politically a very intelligent thing to do.
But I think the Johnson administration will go down in history, unfortunately, as a bad administration because of Vietnam.
Vietnam destroyed him, and all the other things, I think, are second to none.
And finally, what were your perceptions of Two?
President Two?
As I say, I only observed him.
I never spoke a word to the man in my life.
He seemed...
I don't know where he came from.
I don't know anything about his background.
I don't know how he was elected.
I think he was an honorable man, apparently.
When I went to his inauguration in 66, he seemed to be...
Very much accepted by the people.
Of course, the people that were there to applaud him were probably his friends.
I don't know.
But I really don't have any in-depth opinions about two, frankly.
And I apologize.
That's fine.
Are there any other things that you can think of that would be interesting to tell me or that you'd like to talk about?
Well, I would hope we learn from it.
I think the United States should have learned from it.
I'm not sure we have.
I see the same thing raising its ugly head in Honduras.
If we're not careful, we're going to get the same thing down there.
I don't know how you handle terrorism, and that's really what it was.
The things that the Viet Cong did are incomprehensible to the American mind.
The tunnels they dug.
There are hospitals underground.
Hospitals dug underground.
Where did they put all the dirt?
No one's ever seen the dirt yet.
When they tunneled out, what were they doing with the dirt?
I mean, they literally carried stuff for hundreds of miles on their back.
And they're just a very ingenious, innovative people.
And I think if we fought them for a thousand years, we'd never beat them because they just had wings.
We couldn't live the way they live.
Our guys can't live underneath a rice paddy with leeches in their body for a week.
They can't live underground in tunnels for months and never come up.
They're like rats.
And I don't mean that disparagingly, but that's the way they, they live like animals.
And there's, you know, if we learned anything, it was said before we ever got involved in Vietnam, but don't ever again get caught in a ground war in Asia, because they'll destroy you.
The only way we ever beat the Japanese was to bomb them.
Why do you think it is that they seem to have this ability to do these things?
Do you think it was a fact of the way they had been raised culturally?
Sure, it's part of their culture, yeah.
No doubt about it.
They're very, very patient people.
They were very strong-willed people.
They're very proud people.
And, again, they just have a different framework on what's important.
The Americans are very impatient.
I mean, I just got back from North Yemen, which is the same way.
Time means nothing to them.
They show you a house they've lived in for 800 years.
A family lived in the same house for 800 years.
I mean, you can have a meeting with them at 3 o'clock this afternoon.
They might show up next Sunday and think nothing of it.
I mean, what's a week when you're talking about civilization?
And that's kind of the way the North, the Vietnamese are.
And the Asiatic mind is just that way.
It's not quite like, you know, you tend to hear about the Mexican mind on maana, you know.
Well, tomorrow is not very far off.
These people are talking in years.
They're talking about decades.
They're talking about centuries.
Big difference.
And we Americans will never comprehend that thinking.
Never.
How much importance would you place on the survival factor as far as their ability to do these things?
Do you think that that was important, the fact that it was in their country and that they were fighting for their lives, or not necessarily just their lives, their home?
Well, I guess there's some of that.
I mean, I've never talked to a Viet Cong, but obviously they were dedicated.
They were dedicated to something, be it Buddha or Ho Chi Minh.
I don't know.
But they were dedicated, and boy, they thought nothing about dying.
I was in a hospital one day, an American hospital in the field with Humphrey, and Westmoreland was with us.
And there were all these American troops in these cots in this field army hospital that had been wounded more than four hours.
I mean, someone with their legs blown off, still bleeding from it.
On the end cot in that tent was a Viet Cong who'd been wounded.
So the Americans brought him in to try to patch him up.
He had one arm blown off and both his legs blown off at the knees and all these other marks of, I guess he stepped in a mine or something.
But here he is in an American hospital, set up in that cot and spit at Westmoreland.
Now, that's either a very crazy person or a very dedicated, faithful servant.
And my guess is it's the latter.
Yeah.
Yeah.
That's the mentality our troops are fighting.
Our troops are out there saying, why am I here?
I'll be home soon.
I'll be here for a year.
I hope I don't die today.
Or I hope when I climb, I hope that snake doesn't bite me.
They're in an environment that's completely alien to them, in a jungle.
And these people, life doesn't mean that much to them.
It's whatever's inside them that makes them tick.
And I don't know what that is.
But they're very dedicated, and they're very difficult, and they're very tough.
Thanks.
You're welcome.
How many people are you interviewing?
